intro: Corispermum tibeticum var. pilocarpum, commonly known as the Tibetan sand mustard, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of the Tibetan Plateau. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many economically important crops and weeds. The plant is characterized by its small, yellow flowers and distinctive, hairy leaves adapted to the harsh, arid environment. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or sandy habitats. Due to its unique morphology and ecological niche, it is of interest to botanists studying plant adaptation to extreme conditions.
